solution_line_template: Since Darryl has {darryl_books} books, Lamont, who has twice the number of books Darryl has, has {darryl_books}*{twice_multiplier} = <<{darryl_books}*{twice_multiplier}={lamont_books}>>{lamont_books} books.
The total number of books both Darryl and Lamont has is {lamont_books}+{darryl_books} = <<{lamont_books}+{darryl_books}={darryl_lamont_total}>>{darryl_lamont_total} books.

To have the same number of books as Lamont, Loris needs {loris_needs_more} more books, meaning she has {lamont_books}-{loris_needs_more} = <<{lamont_books}-{loris_needs_more}={loris_books}>>{loris_books} books.
In total, the three has {darryl_lamont_total}+{loris_books}= <<{darryl_lamont_total}+{loris_books}={total_books_three}>>{total_books_three} books
